This review is not very articulate. You did not really explain why and how 
a significant amount of points you brought up were bad. I understand that 
movies are subjective, especially on the humor side of this film. However 
if you want to avoid a negative reaction, especially if your opinion is 
against what the greater masses of the public think, then you have to be 
deliberate in making your points clear. For example in your Thanos section 
you stated that his voice just sounded like Josh Brolin's voice... WHY is 
that a bad thing, what did you not like about it? You also claimed he has 
no flare... good start but how do you want him to flare or what kind of 
flare should he have? Explain what you mean by "flare", because you throw 
around several terms that I am not familiar with (I assume your audience 
will not be familiar either) and I won't know what you mean or I will 
misunderstand you. In other videos you claim your biggest problem with this 
movie is it does not have good storytelling... WHY doesn't it have good 
storytelling, what specific problems with the story's structure bother 
you?? This feels like a hastily done review that you wanted to make sure 
was released the day GotG came out, and instead of the usual quality 
reviews pretended to be quality by throwing around some fancy critic terms 
without explaining them or what you mean.﻿

While growing up, my father used to read some of his marvel comics

Gamora, as well as Thanos (ok, admittedly by ripping off Darkseid).    The 
MCU Drax is a watered down joke of the original character, or even the 
gritty, de-powered merc he became in the Annihilation war series, that was 
the basis for the MCU version.   Gamora also poorly portrayed!   Starlin 
wrote (as well as drew) both those characters with such gravity, and 
mystique.   This movie....UGH.﻿

Re:  Language (Universal translator was obviously implied)

Re:  Quill -
(1) I disagree completely.  From the opening scene, Quill really felt like 
a geeky Han Solo.  In fact, the fact he "forgot" his date was on the ship 
was HILARIOUS!
(2) I loved the kid in the beginning.  Every moment I saw him, I thought 
"That's small Chris Pratt!" and I loved when he screamed.  It *REALLY* 
worked.
(3) the "romance" between the Gamora and Quill was fine.  He was hitting on 
her, and it's established he's sort of a player in the opening scene.

Re: Gamora - I largely agree.  I think I should point out that her 
Drax-fight wasn't necessarily a "rescue" scenario, but the 2? ship fighting 
rescues... I'll count.  Still, if we see her kick ass in the sequal, all is 
forgiven.  That's the only thing that really missed.

re:  Drax  - I completely disagree.  He can't act, and that was played up 
as he's an alien and doesn't get it.  It was both meta and deadpan.  Is he 
the Rock?  No.  But the Rock isn't even the Rock most of the time.  Drax 
was fun and great.

Re:  Rocket - I think this was as close to perfect as it could have been. 
 I can't say I laughed at the "fake laugh", but it was still a solid 
performance.  He is the breakout character here.

Re:  Groot - I admit his acting was a bit... weird.  But I didn't hate him. 
 He was so close to being annoying and yet never went over the edge.  He 
was fun and quasi-funny.

Re:  Kosmo - I wanted a speaking line for him.  Oh well.

And yeah, GOTG is going to return.  This was AMAZING.﻿

And worth noting:
http://boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=3885&p=.htm

"Marvel's Guardians of the Galaxy ruled the box office this weekend with a 
fantastic $94 million. That's easily the biggest debut ever for an August 
release; the previous record holder, The Bourne Ultimatum, opened to $69.3 
million in 2007."

Re:  Thanos:
(1)  I saw the motion capture.  It might have been a bit too much.
(2) I admit, though, you're right.  The villains here were REALLY under 
developed.  I don't know how they'd really explore Thanos w/o having him 
beat the snot out of somebody (Beating Ronan would have helped I admit);

Re:  Ronan:
(1) I disagree about the makeup - this felt really weird.
(2) For a genocidal treacherous terrorist, this had no character.
(3) Re:  Dancing - this actually felt right.  While universal translators 
OBVIOUSLY exist, the movie went to lengths to explain how mannerisms don't 
translate.  Heck, Groot's language apparently doesn't even translate! 
 Picard could have translated Groot more than the universal translators 
could!  I completely bought Thanos having a "wait, what?" moment.

Re:  Nebila - I kind of agree.  But her escaping was pretty nice.

Re:  Nova - it was pretty light, I agree.  However I loved the Tholian Web. 
 Nova Corps = Federation... that's all you really need to know.

Re:  Yondu - it was space Merle.  But that was kind of okay with me.

However, I completely disagree w/ the "we didn't deliver him" - it WAS 
heavily implied from the mother at the beginning of the movie.

Re:  Collector - he was horrible, I agree.  But he got Kosmo in there. 
 However, I'm VERY happy that his collection was destroyed by his slave.  A 
very good end for such a sadistically jerkish character.

Re:  End Scene(s).  It really was a great as I expected, but I admit the 2 
after credit scenes weren't enough.  If they had a Nebula scene with her on 
the ship reporting the Thanos, it would have been great.

Finally, I loved this movie.  I would seriously go back and look at Gunn's 
other work because of this.

End of the day, this movie felt a little SMALL, but many people are 
comparing it favorably to the original Star Wars and I largely agree.  It 
felt more Star Trek to me, but it was AMAZING.

Really? I liked Guardians more than Captain America 2. I'm only 22 seconds 
into the review but I have a feeling we're going to disagree on several 
things... Let's see what you caught, because I'm more of a 'is it fun/feel 
right' type of movie goers rather than a nuts/bolts/critical watcher.

Edit: On Thanos: All I needed to know on how bad a he is are the reactions 
of other powerful entities to him. In Avengers Loki locks up when Thanos's 
mouth piece reminds him of Thano's power. Ronan, a total jerk that had 0 
compunction at attacking someone, backed off once Thanos faced him. These 
guys (Loki, Ronan) take a whole crew of heroes to take down... a mere 
thought of Thanos taking action against them shut them down.

Last thoughts: Seems you wanted a more 'serious/angsty' movie. The trailers 
did not present the movie in this vain and I enjoyed what was presented as 
it was presented. Could it have been better? Yes, Gamora is one sore spot 
for me and the attempt at romance had me shaking my head, as well as a few 
other points. But they did a good job of giving us a concise background of 
each character, paced the movie well and made sure that most of the set up 
moments paid off.﻿

not having a clue who any of the characters were.

filling it with goofs and light nods to the original books.

easter eggs in the background. With small character cameos ( such as Nova) 
cool items in the Collectors shop ( there were a few, but I was hoping for

Marvel cinema.

player at the beginning. The most exciting part of that movie for me, was

I think people are way off base with the intentions of this cameo. And I 
don't like the idea that this movie being self contained all the way down 
to the end credits scene (while also hinting to the future with the Thanos 
scene), is being seen as a negative.

Howard the Duck totally fit with this movie and was a perfect inclusion. 
And above all else, I think the cameo is mostly a nod to his creator Steve 
Gerber, who also wrote some of the original Guardians comics. 
It does not mean Marvel is now spearheading a new Howard franchise (of 
course anything's possible) it was just a nod to an obscure comic character 
in a film about obscure comic characters. It was a great treat for fans we 
shouldn't over analyze these things and I don't think we should be mad if 
we don't get what we specifically want from a post credits scene. Those are 
gifts for us fans in the know and we don't really need them.
And how is a talking duck disrespecting the subject matter of a movie 
featuring a talking raccoon? That was a perfect post credits scene for the 
movie it succeeded.

I disagree on a lot of the review, and agree on some, Gamora could have 
been greater, as well as Ronan, but I think this was a big win and it looks 
like it will be a huge success. This means a lot for other unknown or C and 
D level properties having a shot at the big screen. And saying it was a 
drop down to 'TROMA level' just sounds like trolling. I just can't believe 
that is serious. ﻿

Regarding Vin Diesel, Groot was my personal favourite character of the film 
and I though Vin Diesel's voice acting brought a lot to the table, he has a 
great voice and his ability to voice act with such few words solely through 
how he spoke and expressed them was stunning. I watch a ton of anime most 
of it in Japanese(which is why in your Godzilla review your 
mispronunciation of Ken Watanabe's name bothered me so much) and because of 
that when I listen to voice action I listen for the emotion of the 
performance, this language barrier has helped me more strongly appreciate 
voice acting and I already loved it to begin with and I could hear Vin 
Diesel's voice coming from Groot and that isn't a bad thing because I still 
saw Groot as a character before I thought of Vin Diesel.

It is the same thing though to a lesser extent with Thanos, he had the 
right amount of intimidation and calmness in his voice, and as a character 
he was quite foreboding, Ronan betrayed him and had an Infinity Stone and 
said he was his next target and Thanos didn't seem to care, he is so 
confident in his power that he doesn't see Ronan as a threat even with the 
stone, this shows great insight into why he is the big bad, he sees the 
power to destroy a planet in his enemies hands and he just doesn't care, 
and even at the end of the Avengers when his emissary tells him that going 
against Earth is like courting death he simply smiles and if we take it as 
courting the Marvel interpretation of Death(as in the character) it makes 
it even more terrifying because he has been unable to woo her so it could 
be seen as him smiling at an impossible task.﻿

May I start by thanking Grace for all her wonderful work on +Beyond The 
Trailer. Now that we've got it out of the way, let's move on to your review 
of +Guardians of the Galaxy. I completely disagree with your read on the 
movie. I am an avid DC Comic Book Reader and NEW to the Marvel Universe. 
Over the last year, as the Marvel franchises have been building up, I'd 
begun reading a lot of the X-Men & Avengers series'. For the most part, my 
enjoyment or lack thereof has mirrored yours when reviewing these movies. I 
fully understand the position you took with some of the character 
development. We can all agree, when making a movie which includes so many 
characters with an existing expanded universe, it's going to a challenge 
for the any director/story teller. Personally, Considering the plot line 
and time allotted, Gunn set it up about as well as you can. I believe the 
comic book fan in all of us should accept movie incarnations as being 
slightly different from original source material. It's near impossible for 
the adaptations to mirror one another. Marvel is obviously trying to tie 
all of the movies together into it's own split storyline & expanded 
universe. Ultimately, at the end of the day, I think as hard-core comic 
book fans we should be open to the limitations these movies may have. Enjoy 
the movies for what they are, without constantly comparing it to the source 
material. I've never read a Guardians Comic Book, but did research the 
origin stories prior to going to the screening. Look, it was't perfect (The 
Collector character had so much potential & Howard the Duck's cameo was 
completely lame)...Still, it was a fun ride and left me wanting more. Like 
I said Grace, this is the first time I've disagreed with you on a movie. 
You're still the best in the business and I look forward to the next 
installment of BYT! :-)﻿

Grace... I love you woman, but I definitely do not agree with you on this 
one on your overall feeling about it. Lower your expectations?!? I thought 
this movie was AWESOME!!! Let me start this comment with the fact that I 
LOVED the old 90s show Farscape. From watching your reviews and videos over 
the years I'm almost certain that you've never seen the show. The entire 4 
seasons are on Netflix though if you'd like to check out the first few 
episodes of it. If you do it's a bit slow at first till John Crichton goes 
through the wormhole and thrown onto the alien ship, Moya. I mention that 
show because the moment I saw the trailer for this film back when they 
first released it that show is IMMEDIATELY what came to mind for me while 
watching it. Those of you who have seen the show will understand why and 
probably agree about loving this film if you loved that show too. They have 
a similar feel to each other. I wouldn't be surprised if James Gunn and the 
writers of GotG were big fans of the show as well.
 I admit, I can agree with some of the things you said about GotG, Grace. 
Like that it kinda has a more 90s feel to it (which I loved). And about the 
need for a universal translator on them all. Which going back to the 
Farscape reference they handled quick and easy in the first episode once he 
was on the alien craft and could have done something similar here. That Zoe 
Saldana wasn't very good acting wise, but then she never really is. She's 
like a younger version of Halle Berry. She's a pretty face and a just 
enough 'token ethnic' for the studio heads to shove her into everything 
they want someone with a 'little more ethnic look'. But Zoe's not really 
some great oscar worthy actress or anything. And neither is Halle Berry.
 Dave Batista I thought did an EXCELLENT job as his part. He was playing a 
guy (at least here) that was suppose to be more wooden and literal. Since, 
like Rocket said, his people take everything literally. Maybe he's not like 
that in the comics, which I've never read any of the comics with him in 
them, but that's the impression I got of the character here.
  I too wish they had done more with Nebula. I thought Karen Gillan looked 
F**KING AWESOME in her look for the character (again no idea about her in 
the comics). They didn't use her enough in the film to flesh her out and 
show how bad ass she apparently is. But she looked amazing as her that's 
for sure. Maybe it's just because I love redheads and loved her as Amy Pond 
in Doctor Who. But hell I'd cosplay as Nebula myself. She looked AWESOME! 
Blue chicks are hot :p. Farscape fans will agree with me on that one too ;).
 I would have liked a bit more about the Kree Empire too.They gave little 
impression as to just how badass the Kree are other then just Ronin. They 
are suppose to be pretty widespread and a dominant empire in the galaxy, 
right? Along side the Shi'ar  and the Skrull, the other dominant empires in 
the galaxy.
 I think you, Grace, have a couple of issues with a film like this going 
into it. One you are HUGE into comics as well as films. So you go into it 
with all this knowledge of the characters in the comics and everything 
about the storylines surrounding it so when it's not what you feel it 
should be you tend to already want to down grade it in the back of your 
mind. And that it doesn't fully explain things you feel needed to be more 
in-depth about that the rest of us aren't that concerned with. (I will also 
admit that I would have liked if they had said what each 'stone' was and 
which one it was that they had there. Which I'm guessing it was the Soul 
gem.) I know you also are not really that into Sci-fi stuff. So that's 
another 'meh' reason against it in your eyes. Not to mention the fact that 
you tend to worry a bit much sometimes about 'oscar worthy performances' 
from every movie you see. Perhaps I'm being a little to judgmental on these 
points about you though. Except for the sci-fi thing. You know you don't 
really care for sci-fi stuff. Go on, admit it :p.
 I did think the after credits sequence was completely throw away and 
stupid with Howard the Duck. They could have had The Collector finding his 
other gem that he was given in Thor: The Dark World in the rubble to remind 
us that he already had one of them beforehand. And/or show him talking to 
someone else connected to them about it if he even has some other purpose 
for them then just collecting them for himself. Like maybe Adam Warlock in 
Phase3 of Marvel's films? Hmm? Maybe... hopefully. Magics, space, other 
dimensions, Thanos & the Infinity Gems, Great place to have put him or 
eluded to him since he's connected to all that. 
 So while I can agree with you on some of your points I can't agree with 
you on your overall stance on the film. This movie was fun. VERY fun! And 
yes there were a few bits and pieces that where out of place here and 
there. But overall it was a DAMN great time! And one hell of an addition to 
the Marvel cinematic universe. One that I look forward to revisiting 
whenever they do go back to it. :)
(And forgive me if I went on a bit to long or if I rambled a bit. I have a 
tendency to do that.)﻿

Grace, I'm with you on this. I know I'll get flack but dammit if we don't 
demand better Marvel is just going to continue to go by the numbers. Ronan 
was so one note, and honestly why reveal Thanos if he's not going to DO 
anything. I loved Rocket and Groot though.

 I was really hoping they would take this opportunity to explore and build 
this colorful new universe (after failing to do any of that in the second 
Thor movie). There's nothing here that stuck in my head visually as other 
worldly or exotic or gave me that "I want to GO there" feeling. It feels 
less inspired and more like a product. While I liked the songs in the 
soundtrack I just felt like they overused them and were just yelling in my 
ear at a certain point. It's like wanting to shout at a bratty kid to turn 
down the god damn radio.

I agree about Gamora, but I think Drax is far worse. He's called the 
destroyer, but gets his ass handed to him throughout the entire movie! And 
I agree on Bautista's line delivery. He EXCELS at deflating jokes.

 I disagree with you about the pace though. I think is was quite brisk. In 
fact it felt like they left important things out (like who are these Kree 
fellows, and what exactly are the nova corps , and why  should I care if 
this planet is destroyed besides it being generally unpleasant.) for 
completely unimportant things like Nebula and yes THANOS. I honestly 
believe this movie could have done without his physical reveal (which was 
lackluster as well I might add) similar to how you don't see the Emperor in 
Star Wars in person until the third freaking film.

I don't think I disliked it as much as you, I mean I still hope to see a 
sequel, but I do feel a bit let down.﻿

Last honest reviewer. GR has the credentials and enthusiasm to be entitled 
to a review like this. BUT I WISH SHE HAD HELD OUT FOR THREE WEEKS TO GIVE 
THIS "Tell us how you REALLY feel, Grace" review. Part of being a fan means 
not spoiling other viewers' enthusiasm - but this review does that, in 
spades.

This is the sort of review that should be made in a closed meeting room to 
the GOTG team as they contemplate what worked and didn't work, before they 
dive into the next movie. Otherwise they drink their own KoolAde (due to 
glowing reviews from reviewers who haven't read a comic since Archie in 
grade school) the way Raimi did with the original Spiderman movies, and the 
series will go down hill. (GR may not have the RIGHT solutions, but at 
least she would make Gunn think things through more carefully.)

I think GR deserves all the "thumbs down" which are surely based on the 
"judgment" contained in her review, and not the quality of the review. Try 
to criticize GRR Martin in a book review on Amazon and you get the same 
thing! GR is a thoughtful critic who is deeply involved with what she 
watches (she is actually a FAN, not a reviewer who doesn't have a clue and 
just follows the crowd), unlike the many, many "critics" out there who just 
mouth what audiences want to hear so they can get readers and viewers. For 
that reason, I join the minority who gives her a "thumbs up." Even though I 
HATE this review. It's judgments and conclusions anyway, but not the 
careful thought that led to those judgments and conclusions.

But really Grace - next time save a "spoiler" like this for a recap a few 
weeks down the road - because this didn't spoil the plot points, it spoiled 
the PARTY.﻿

This movie, for better and worse, was pure frenetic energy. It is frat boy 
Star Wars - of the moment, flashy, full of youthful energy. At best, you 
feel like a giddy kid watching it, buoyed by the golden oldies soundtrack, 
cartoon elements, and awesome gadgets,weaponry, sets, and makeup/costumes. 
But then, you're brought down periodically by cliches, death and 
destruction, and confusing storylines with an overpopulation of flimsy 
characters. There are enough feel good moments that I'm happy I saw it, but 
I don't know how to classify the experience and where it would or could fit 
in the Marvel universe I'm familiar with and have emotional attachment to 
(Captain fan). That's just it, no emotional attachment here. Laughs and 
wows, but those don't hold up a second viewing.﻿

Grace...I can't believe you'd actually compare this movie to Thor the Dark 
World...just...just wow.
I also disagree with you saying that no one character get's enough 
attention. I came out of that movie pretty attached to characters. I never 
felt that the background stories slowed things down. Also...Peter Quill's 
character had several moments in which I looked at him, and thought, this 
guy's sweet.
His name is funny and meaningful...its just a delivery at the end. It 
didn't need to be at the beginning.
As someone who's not familiar with the character from comics...I FELT 
CONNECTED TO THE CHARACTER. You're point seems moot, at least to me. I also 
loved the costume designs.
I will grant you, the different colored chick was kind Treck like, but I 
didn't mind.
I could see where you're coming from with Gamora? I suppose? They all speak 
the same language because quill has a translation chip...the yellow text 
said so in his modification....just like it said rocket had 5 counts of 
arson.
I'll agree with Drax...I felt little emotion.
Rocket is awesome...yes.
Groot was a needed element in my opinion. He was just great.
They did not barely escape...the franchise is funny.
Thanos...was...yeah. He kind of didn't seem that scary.
And yeah...Marvel has an issue with making memorable villains for some 
reason. Which makes me greatly sad.
I truly believe he was so dumbstruck by the idiocy that he literally lost 
track?
Nebula was pretty sweet...the voice was changed...the jaw switch was a bit 
rushed. It was not a mouse click, I can tell you that much. It was too many 
frames though. That aside, I don't know about mercury from the comics, and 
it may be bias from my love for the actress herself, but the character was 
really interesting to me, and unlike Thanos held an air of mystery to her. 
Which was wonderful.
I didn't really think her anger was manufactured...
The Nova core were pretty much just there, I'll grant you that. They did 
provide use at the end to some extent though, don't you lie. They were 
pretty sweet at the end.
There was a lot of death, and it was pretty neat. No, it wasn't a did that 
guy just die? It was a HOLY SHIT THAT GUY...no....no guys...no.
The Ravengers were the hillbillies of the movie. I don't think they needed 
to discuss it at the beginning of the movie. I really don't. And you'd be 
surprised how many are demanding a sequel. Probably not after reading your 
comment section, but still.
The collector...literally did not need to be in there. His only purpose was 
explanation...so yeah...I'll give ya that one.
That end credit sequence was such a troll. I laughed so loud at the end.
It's not a tough sell beyond hardcore fans. I had a friend who dissed the 
movie as fantastic four and a half up until she saw it, came out of it 
loving the movie. She really dislikes super hero movies, but loved this 
film. If that tells ya something about the film.
That duck...was stupidly strange?
What...are you talking about with professionalism? They had plenty in 
visuals alone. Did you even listen to yourself? Marvel studios started out 
with people who broke away from big studios and started from the ground 
up...
I personally enjoyed it greatly, though there were a couple of moments 
where I was channeling my inner cinemasins and going: Nope...no you should 
be dead. I don't care if you're enhanced or what not. You're in 
space...exposed...you should be dead.

On the not of death...I really didn't mind it. It drove home a darkness to 
this humor. And...to be frank...this movie was never portrayed to me as 
something you'd want to bring your young kids too. Though the one's in the 
theater with me were laughing at deaths...which is a whole other basket of 
apple's I'll leave on the floor for later.
I'm going to end my little rant/counter/debate/thing here for now.﻿

Saldana played the same character as in other movies; I thought Gamora was 
distinct from Uhura and the Avatar Princess, but what wasn't distinct was 
Gamora and Black Widow. Seriously, Gamora is just a space Black Widow, 
which is why I feel like the character felt stale.

moment in Ronan said he didn't remember murdering Drax's family that it was 
going to be revealed that Drax had made it up because I at no point felt 
like this was a man who had seen his family murdered before his eyes.

battle at the end, but overall I agree with you. This movie deserves a 
solid "B" but is nothing to write home about, just a fun way to pass the 
time.﻿

Okay, I don't usually comment on Youtube because it doesn't amount to much 
of anything, especially on a popular channel such as this. Opinions get 
lost in the sea of comments and I doubt Grace will get to see this.

As a foreword I enjoy Beyond the Trailer and like Grace opinion. While I 
think it's off a tinge because she puts too much industry thought behind 
her feelings, but that is how she attacks it. Reviews are entirely 
subjective, even while some may think they're supposed to be objective.

Another bit of information about myself that I'd like to share is that I'm 
not a fan of the Marvel Cinematic Universe. I feel the business model works 
as that, a business model. Most movies feel middling and purely exist to 
make money and for set up. There are some notable stand outs that I feel 
are movies in their own right and are damn right good to boot(Avengers, Cap 
1 and 2 and thankfully Guardians.

Guardians is the breath of fresh air I think the Marvel cinematic universe 
needs. Fresh characters and a feel all its own. Yes, it takes place in the 
Marvel Cinematic Universe, but it never feels like that is a fault to it. 
It doesn't obey the same rules, or adhere to the same look, or directing 
style...like with Avengers, you can feel the director getting to do what he 
wants to do, which can't be said about the majority of the other films.

As far as point by point dislikes of the film go, I had a few:

*Gamora does feel like the weakest character of the Guardians, but not 
particularly a bad one. Her role doesn't feel completely perfunctory like 
the likes of Black Widow or Hawkeye. The movie can't work without Gamora, 
she brings something to the team.

*Ronin and Nebula are the weakest characters in the film, both in terms of 
character and acting. I mean, but is it worth complaining about this now? 
As if Marvel already hasn't had this problem in the past? OUtside of Loki 
(and MAYBE Red Skull) are any other villains in the Marvel Cinematic 
Universe good? They're all secondary factors in the plot and just around to 
be beaten by the good guys at the end. At least Ronin earned a laugh or two 
which is more than I can say about Killian or Malakite.

*The Action.  It's okay, but it isn't great. James Gunn's hand to hand 
fights aren't as great as some other Marvel films, but it does its job. The 
characters are strong enough to have you invested in their fates regardless 
of how amazing the action scenes are. In the end I still cared who won and 
lost, which isn't the same that can be said about films with arguably 
better action scenes(Transformers films, Thor The Dark World, etc)


The shot you took at Dave Bautista is odd to me...I think you might not 
have gotten what he was doing with the character. His comedic timing was 
excellent and I think he might actually be the funniest character in the 
film. He is the break out role imo...everyone knew the rest of the all star 
cast was going to deliver, he was the one X-factor and I'm happy to say he 
made Drax one of my favorite characters.

I don't think the movie was that confusing for the uninitiated. I went with 
my girlfriend and a ton of friends who don't read comics or know much lore 
concerning Thanos and that didn't affect their viewing. Would it be 
enriched by outside knowledge, sure, but that is the problem with expanded 
universes...and why I got out of reading mainstream comics...you shouldn't 
have to read every limited or ongoing to enjoy the work. They do not inform 
the works, but merely enhance them-that's how I see it.

That 'professionalism' you're talking about might be more akin to 'death of 
the author'. Should creators put aside their artistic integrity to create 
more assembly line middling films so that everything seems more uniform and 
'professional'?  I'd much rather see really good movies individually than 
worry about the promise of something greater to come and have to watch a 
ton of vanilla films.  
Edgar Wright has already left, and from what Guardians and Avengers showed 
me is that a creator with a vision is an asset to this cinematic universe.

Those are my thoughts.
Normally I'm a naysayer and usually arguing against people mindlessly 
praising these Marvel movies, but with this movie I'm a believer. Cut away 
all the Marvel Universe BS and you still have a solid movie.
That is important to me.

Oh, and for the record, I've seen it twice.
Probably going to go see it a third in a minute or two.﻿

Now that I've seen the movie for myself, I can say I understand many of the 
complaints made about it.  I'm responding on Grace because hers seems to be 
the most thought out ones I've seen so far.  I have to agree that until the 
numbers are in and the 2nd week box office comes around, it's impossible to 
determine audience response just from a personal opinion of the film.   
Here's the parts I disagreed with.  I think the characters got enough 
screen time, and the movie did not feel crowded at all.  As to the issue of 
Gamora having to be saved, I agree with the first part to a point but the 
second save (and there were only two so-called "saves" in the movie, so I 
don't get the "she had to be saved a lot" thing.)  The first one I thought 
that she was restraining herself because she was trying to make a point and 
I feel that it's the actor's and director's fault for not actually 
conveying this strongly enough.  Otherwise I was baffled why she would have 
even let these other prisoners grab her.  For instance if after the Peter 
"saves" her scene if she proceeded to take everyone out in under a second 
and just gave a "hey, I was trying to make a point that I had changed, I 
didn't really need you to step in" look on her face with Quill looking on 
and feeling a little like a idiot.  It would have been in line with the 
feel of the film and made the point I believe they were trying to make.  
Her second save?  Grace, seriously?  She was in space and even with her 
enhancements she was dying.  Whose butt was she supposed to kick after 
being ejected from her ship?  Dark Matters?  Solar Flares?   I think the 
point of the scene was for Peter so show there was more to him, and I think 
it was done effectively.   I do agree that I wish there was more Thanos or 
he did more, but I think Marvel has a plan and I'm going with it since 
everyone has been wrong about it every time they announce a movie.  The 
rest of the review I believe was as fair as you could get for not liking 
the film pretty much at all as you did.  I don't agree with a lot of your 
review, but as I said, I can see and understand where these complaints are 
coming  from.  It just hit me in the opposite way.  I loved the movie.  We 
both totally agree that baby Groot. . ADORBS!!!!!﻿

Points:
* I felt emotionally moved by Peter's grief related to his mother.
- I agree about him being too Kirk-like
* I wish Gamora had been more badass like she is in the comics and didin't 
have a thing with Peter.
* I thought Bautista did alright-well. This role didn''t require a lot of 
emotion. Bautista is to Drax as Arnold is to the Terminator, so I thought 
the casting was apt.
* agree that Thanos and Ronan were underwhelming
*I disagree about Nebula. I thought her relationships with Gamora and 
Thanos were interesting. I think one reason why you might have liked Karen 
Gillan in the role was because she did not convey a whole lot of emotions 
or use a lot of acting muscles, but I think that was a conscious decision 
since she was like a cyborg. I thought the scene where Thanos calls Gamora 
his favorite daughter and Nebula has a very slight reaction as if she was 
somewhat hurt by that comment was a nice nuance.
* I completely agree with you about the end credits-scene. THAT WAS THE 
WORST OF THE MARVEL STUDIOS END CREDITS SCENES. I want them to respect the 
fans more. The very last scenes for Thor TDW and Captain America TWS were 
not that great, either. I really hope they know where they're going.

That being said, I really liked the film overall. I thought the Guardians 
all worked even if they could've been better. The movie had some really 
great one-liners. Some good action sequences. I liked the retro soundtrack 
set to space-age visuals. I'm biased cuz I'm a hardcore Marvel fan, but I 
thought the film was up there with X-Men DoFP. Thought Captain America The 
Winter Soldier was better, though.﻿

I saw the movie tonight in IMAX and I would say seeing it in that format 
adds another layer of entertainment so I would suggest watching it that way 
before it's out of theaters. Now as far as the film goes I'll follow the 
formula in your review and start with Peter Quill. I'm not all that 
familiar with the comics, but I felt the movie did a great job of 
establishing the connections Peter had with his mother and the mix tape, 
but I do agree with you that it would have made more of an impression if we 
had heard his mother call him Star Lord during the flashback or even within 
flashback. I understand why it wasn't until the end of the movie that he 
had opened the present because I feel that by opening it Peter, in a way, 
was letting go of the only family he had so it makes sense to me that when 
he accepted the trust of his friends he was finally able to let go. Overall 
I felt that Chris Pratt worked very well in this role because he has this 
nice quirky presence about him which adds a level to Quills character. I 
understand your points on how Gamora was written and I agree they should 
have given her more breakout moments of being a supreme assassin, but I 
also feel that the movie was taking place during a time where she was done 
with seeing people die so I feel we saw a Gamora that tried to avoid 
conflict, but I will agree that she should have been able to save herself 
in the prison and it would have been nice to see her and Drax have a little 
more conflict. I'll say based off Zoe Saldana's performance of Gamora that 
she did a great job of portraying the character and the interesting dynamic 
I felt she added was that Gamora is more of a sister to Peter than a love 
interest and Zoe conveyed that really well to me. Now Drax was an 
interesting character that had many levels and I feel that Dave Bautista 
did really well with the role and lines he was given. What I gathered from 
Dave's performance was that Drax is an emotionally destroyed man who takes 
everything as serious and literal which I felt was done well and I can't 
remember the exact line, but when the Guardians are in the guard tower Drax 
has a line that almost sounds like something from Shakespeare. I really 
think that Dave took Drax and made it his own, but like I said before I 
would have liked to see more of a transition with Drax trusting Gamora and 
the others. As for Rocket and Groot I really liked them both! I fully agree 
with you on Thanos that his reveal should have been made more ominous and 
foreboding, but instead it was just a casual turn of the chair and he just 
didn't feel like a mastermind so I hope he gets a lot more fleshed out in 
the sequel. I really liked Ronan as the main villain because he struck me 
as a cross between Darth Vader and Darth Maul, but I don't think they 
should have killed him off because he had a lot of villain potential. A 
villain I was really looking forward to was Nebula for two main reasons, 1. 
She had a really cool and interesting makeup design and 2. I was familiar 
with the actress that plays her. I really liked Nebula because she is now 
the first female villain of the cinematic universe and has potential to be 
the next big bad of the marvel movies, by this I mean she would be second 
to Loki. Nebula's main problem I think was that her origin story and what 
Thanos had done to her were glazed over. I feel that if they gave 
individual attention to either Ronan or Nebula we would have a great 
fleshed out villain in the cinematic universe. As for Karen Gillan's 
portrayal I liked it cause she was playing that angry second in command 
that wants to be in control and I liked how her accent came through because 
for some reason villains that have an accent tend to stick with me more, 
but I agree that Nebula and Ronan both could have been fleshed out a little 
more. With Yondu I agree that he should have addressed that he was supposed 
to deliver Peter to his father in the beginning of the movie because for a 
short time during the movie I thought Yondu was Peter's father, but then 
again if the movie wanted me to think then they did a good job of throwing 
me through a loop. Ever since Thor 2 The Collector has just been one of 
those interesting characters that I want to see more of and this movie I 
don't think disappointed because I was able to see the great over the top 
hand gestures that really defines the character and makes him stand out, 
well that and the costuming, but the movie also left me wanting to see more 
of his character and how he will develop and what he will do since his 
collection was destroyed. Last but not least the end credits scene. I 
enjoyed the scene because it gave a funny look at how the Collector was 
just defeated over his ruined collection so he's just going to drink all of 
it away. As for Howard the Duck I thought it was a nice easter egg, but I 
think you're right in the aspect that Marvel at this point only knows what 
will happen in Age of Ultron, but I was not upset because that scene was 
similar to the shwarma scene in the Avengers, but I would have liked to see 
some sort of plot building reveal. Well I hope I've given you some good 
discussion material and I really enjoyed your review and I'm excited to 
hear your thoughts on my really long response. ﻿

I haven't seen the film, but I understand where she's coming from.

The movie may be good, but as a fan of the comics, she feels that the depth 
present in those books is missing here, and that sacrifice in character 
development, in favor of comedy and action, makes the film empty.

Some may think that heart is not an important element in this sort of film, 
but Star Wars had heart, and that anchored the movie and made you want to 
invest your time with them, and so, with the story, and is a large part of 
what makes it memorable. Apparently that is not present here.

Having moments of levity, self-awareness and grounded drama in a movie like 
this, when it works, always elevates the overall narrative, I find.﻿

I saw a couple of reviews from Grace and got to say that lately I tend to 
disagree with her. I think she got "Noah" review wrong, as well as she did 
not get this movie at all. One of the reasons may be she is simply too 
young, or too earnest in her thinking. Or perhaps she likes simpler, dumber 
movies more: I, for example did not find the number of characters and 
places confusing at all. Moreover, her comment on "Starlord" being revealed 
at the end as what his mom called him I thought was a coup of exposition - 
brilliant. Something that most have thought of as being a silly affectation 
of Peter Quill's ego was finally revealed to have a deeper emotional 
meaning - was great and noticeable precisely because of its placement at 
the end of the movie, which was a challenge for us, viewers to slightly 
perhaps reexamine our previous reactions. Same happened with the drunk 
Racoon speech of being assembled / dissembled. These moments gave movie its 
heart. Now imagine if starlord moniker was placed in the beginning - would 
have negated the point. Such basic misunderstanding of movie-making craft, 
and there is plenty of craft and art in this movie, is strange and kinda 
points to a certain lack of sophistication on Grace's part, which also 
explains many disliking Grace's review. And, Grace - instead of admitting 
in your review of Mad Max the Fury Road trailer that you have not seen the 
original Mad Max movies, you should just watch those - they are great, and 
simple enough even for you to get.       ﻿

This is my first time listening to one of your reviews. and I got to say it 
was very disappointing.  You lost me when you compared GotG to CAWS.
This is going to be a long rant so bear with me, let me point out were I 
think you are wrong.
First of All this is a Guardians of the Galaxy movie (not one of the single 
characters, so detailed origins for them will have to wait for other 
movies) 
The Sound Track: It almost hurt me physically when you said you wanted 
"modern" songs in this. They used these songs because Peter was supposed to 
be abducted in the 80's and they are his anchor home.  I could agree with 
an original soundtrack but I was very happy with this (maybe I'm old and 
this is the music I grew up with)
Peter Quill: He is supposed to be a bad person.  He is a charming criminal 
but no a sociopath which is why he tries tries to save the Galaxy.  The 
star lord joke is good because you don't' know why he want to be call that 
and It becomes meaningful at the end when you realize it was his mom's pet 
name.  If they had that at the beginning it would have seem a little 
pathetic every time he used it.
Gamora: I agree with you a little here, she was not used as well as she 
could have. Like you said she is supposed to be the bad-ass of the 
bad-asses, that did not come well in the movie. The think you did not get 
about the stick is that only we used that particular slang try saying that 
in South America and you will probably get Gamora's exact reaction.
Drax: Here is where I disagree almost completely with you.  Batista is not 
a great actor but in this movie they used him excellently.  He was the 
straight man in the comedy routine and was great in it.  I laughed at all 
his lines.  I actually like this a little better than the Drax in the 
comics (and that is a very high complement coming from me because I love 
the existentially conflicted Drax of the comics)
Rocket: I also loved him. nuff said.
Groot: I agree with you that anyone could have voiced him. and he was 
great. I don't think they could have a solo movie. you would get tired of 
them.  similar to what happen in the Hangover with Chao.
I'll just say that the villains were the weak sauce of the movie just like

movie. Hopefully they will get a better villain for the 2nd movie now that

Grace is a conundrum sometimes. My general rule of thumb (even for things 
we mostly agree on) is to expect that she will say something that I 
personally not only disagree with, but don't understand. Her saying that 
only the fans are enjoying this movie is irksome. She should have taken the 
time and got the gamut of reactions before saying something like that. A 
quick Google search would have shown her that most people thought it was a 
good, fun, film. I'm all for different opinions, but at least acknowledge 
you're in the minority and don't be so absorbed in your own opinion that 
you assume most people agreed with you. If you want to say something like 
that then actually take the time and look at the critical and audience 
response first. "....shouldn't be being saved for a sequel, which I think 
right now probably very few people are demanding." Really, Grace? Based on 
what? Because there is a wealth of evidence to the contrary.

 I know you didn't like the film Grace, but try and remove yourself from 
your own opinion and look at the critical and audience reception 
objectively. Judging from the response of people who have seen it(fans and 
non-fans alike) Guardians is on track to be a success and it seems that 
Marvel was correct in green lighting a sequel before Guardians opened 
(we'll know for sure after the box office results come in and how Guardians 
does in the following weeks). And this is a great film for kids. There 
isn't anything mildly inappropriate for them. Honestly I just don't 
understand your criticisms sometimes.﻿

Grace, this is my first ever post on your channel, and I love your shows 
and your reviews.  I don't agree with everything you say but I'm on your 
side with majority of you opinions. 
Now that that's out of the way, I think you're COMPLETELY wrong on your 
review of this film.  This is just like your other guilty pleasures, 
(*ahem, Transformers) she truly misses the mark on this one.
(Come on Grace, how anyone of your caliber likes the Transformers franchise 
is beyond me.)
 
Where to even begin.  You have been saying for weeks, this movie won't 
break 100 million in its opening weekend.  I think it will.  Even with the 
lack of character development the way that Avengers had,   
I think this movie has such a campy, summer feel, even as we’re in August, 
this movie just might have that slow burn to last a whole month, if not 
more.
 
(**I believe one of the reasons why the Avengers did so well was the luxury 
of time.  They had enough time and story to develop each the characters and 
really pitch for a merger movie.  In my opinion, the success of Iron Man 1 
really kick started The Avengers franchise.  If it had been a flop, no 
Avengers. Secondly, when every Marvel movie hints at all the super heroes 
coming together, you just can help but get swept up in the hype.)
 
Where it’s clear that you’re on Team Rocket Raccoon fan club, you’re 
negative opinion on Bautista (aka Drax) was totally FU.  Yes, Rocket had 
many funny and even at time emotional scenes, but Bautista nailed his part 
as Drax.
I think what you complete missed about Drax was that, yes, he was a muscle 
bound killing machine, but he was also a square.  He was like straight out 
of Harvard school of Soldier and all he did was train his body and mind, 
but had no social life.  I normally don’t lol in theaters, and where Rocket 
made me chuckle out loud (especially when he was making fun of the 
Collector in his not so subtle way), I truly LOL on Drax’s bits.  (The bit 
about jokes going over his head, and when Quill was giving his best 
attempts at a pre-battle speech and Drax in the middle of it saying, I 
wasn’t listening.  That was classic.)
 
Oh, and you keep comparing this movie to Star Trek.  Calling it Star Trek 
Light.  Check out Farscape.  This movie has more Farscape element than 
anyone is willing to give it credit.  Even straight down to their uniforms. 
 
I don’t want this to be too long, so I’ll end it here.
I see a lot of remarks slamming Grace.  (The most amount of thumbs down 
I’ve seen under 24 hours) But in Grace’s defense, she’s read the GotG 
comics, knows the Marvel history and Lore (more than most of you guys 
leaving those FU comments).  I think she was just expecting way too much 
out of this movie.  Even though she herself had stated Marvel was taking a 
huge gamble on this one, and she wasn’t expecting much out of it.  She 
really did a disservice to herself by expecting this movie to be somehow 
the new “Star Wars”. 
 
Overall, this movie didn’t have any new.  In fact this movie reminded me a 
lot of Farscape (as mentioned earlier), a bit of Star Trek: Into Darkness.  
But a roaring good fun none the less.  I too wasn’t expecting much, but at 
the end, totally worth it.  Better than Avengers in my opinion.  And not at 
all slow as Grace mentioned.﻿

Hey Grace,

I'm am completely surprised you didn't like Guardians of the Galaxy. I 
think what you missed from the whole thing is that it's the first Space 
Opera that was palatable since Star Wars. You might be thinking it was too 
shallow on a lot of aspects stemming from its sci-fi/fantasy origins but 
that's why it worked. The reason there hasn't been another Star Wars since 
Star Wars is because delving too much into Space Opera aspects of those 
stories bores general audiences. This has been the problem with Dune, 
Stargate, Chronicles of Riddick, and many others. But Guardians of the 
Galaxy had just enough Space Opera to keep the plot moving and prep future 
Marvel movies while filling the rest with a buddy-buddy heist movie. It's 
the latter aspect of the movie that makes this work. Which is also why vast 
majority of critics and audience members like this movie. Everyone at my 
theater was cracking up the whole time. Did you not see this aspect of the 
movie or did you just not appreciate it?

Also, Bautista, to me, was spot on as Drax. His timing was awesome. 
Definitely my favorite character of the movie.

I did notice one last thing which speaks to your point about how Marvel's 
villains, aside from Loki, don't resonate with fans. It's because they 
don't have a character arc. All of Marvel's villains simply serve as a plot 
device for the heroes to grow around. Red Skull, Iron Monger, Whiplash, 
Malekith, Chitauri, and Ronan are assholes from beginning to end without 
any real soul. But this isn't just the problem with the movies. Avengers 
villains generally just suck. That's why, before the movies, X-Men was more 
popular. Villains like Magneto, Sabretooth, Emma Frost, and Mystique had 
character arcs that could have justified solo series for any of them while 
they were villains, and in some cases they did. You can't say that for any 
Avengers villain. Inherently, Marvel has the boring villains. But maybe if 
they can figure something out with Kang, they could have something 
compelling on their hands. What do you think?

I realize everyone has different tastes, but perhaps Grace's disappointment 
in the movie stems from something else.

I try to be gender and colorblind when watching a movie as in real life, 
and so when Gamora and Nebula were under developed I had the other 4 
guardians to comfort me.  If I went in with a focus on the female 
characters, expecting to see a Xena-esque Gamora, and she got this 
Gamora... I'd be VERY disappointed; much like if I went to see the Avengers 
thinking it was the Hawkeye Movie and only got pwned Clint.  But it wasn't 
the Hawkeye movie (it might have been the Black Widow movie though...), and 
this wasn't the Gamora movie.

I suppose what we needed to see was Gamora kicking more tail in the prison, 
but she couldn't have kicked tail before being "not rescued" by Quill, and 
we couldn't spend more time with her during the actual breakout.

Maybe she should have tried to kill Nebula rather than reluctantly not try 
to kill her "sister", who ALSO didn't like Thanos so I could see her trying 
not to kill her.

MAYBE we needed a scene with her VS Ronan w/ the Gem.  I don't know.

Still, I eagerly await a 2nd installment.  If she falls flat THERE too, 
then we'll talk about dropping her from the team.  We could always get 
Moondragon or Phyla-Vell added to the team... or Mantis?  Although Mantis 
might suffer from the same green paint problem.

I realize this is way after the fact, but.... "They needed a professional 
writer on this." Holy wow. REALLY? The writing was f'n brilliant! I mean, I 
get it if it was too much of a "cartoony" comedy for you personally, but 
objectively, this was a really well done script. Go back and watch that 
"round table" heroes(!) scene towards the end, when Quill is basically 
convincing them to all go out and DIE and how they all agree because 
they're all losers who are alone in their own way, so why the hell not die 
with a bunch crazy characters they barely know but actually care about. And 
all the humor played out wonderfully, accentuating both character and 
drama. It was amazing. I won't even touch the "they needed more 
professional actors" line... I don't think we were watching the same movie 
at all.﻿

The first time I watched this film it seemed a bit iffy, stumbling in 
places. It felt a bit like a string of scenes rather than a movie. After 
watching it a second and third time I enjoyed it much more. I think I went 
in with an expectation that the film didn't live up to. Once I knew what I 
was getting however I could sit down and just enjoy it. I think it's main 
issue was a lack of a strong plot, which I forgave afterwards due to how 
fun the movie was. Loved Groot and Rocket (though I agree there wasn't much 
need for Vin Diesel's voice acting). I feel like I got more character from 
Film Drax than the Drax in the comics and felt Zoe Saldana did a reasonable 
job. I liked how Gamora (ironically considering her origins) was in a way 
the moral heart of the group, the one most trying to do the right thing. It 
had a redemptive quality that I thought was nice. Overall despite some 
issues I had a great time watching the movie and would love a sequel, 
though I think doing stand alone films for each of the characters is a 
terrible idea, they work best when interacting with one another. I usually 
agree with your reviews of movies but for once I feel I must disagree. Some 
of the issues you pointed out I just couldn't see and would love to hear 
more from you about it. You are very entitled to your own opinion however, 
and I'm horrified at some of the things I've read in these comments, don't 
let it get to you.

-Jay :). (Using my boyfriends account to be exact). ﻿

Grace, I've been a fan of your channel for along time but this is the first 
time I've drastically disagreed with you. To begin, you brought up that you 
thought the 70's music didn't work and you wanted an orchestral score. I 
thought the songs where expertly selected to help tell the story and build 
Peter Quill's character, and the movie did have a beautiful orchestral 
score composed by Tyler Bates. Next, you argued that Peter Quill needed a 
moment where we find out he's not just pick-up lines and genuinely has a 
heart. For me, that moment was when we find out that he calls himself 
Star-Lord because his mother called him Star-Lord, which is why I suspect 
they left that moment till the end of the film rather than put it at the 
beginning of the film like you suggested. You also mentioned that you felt 
that someone who had not read the comics would not understand the plot or 
connect with the characters. As someone who has never read the comics or 
even heard of these characters, I can personally guarantee you that 
everything made sense to me and I instantly connected with each of the 
Guardians. I also find it contradictory that you would suggest that it's 
detrimental for people to have had to have read the comics to understand 
the movie, but then complain that characters such as Gamora weren't 
represented the way they are in the comics. On the subject of Gamora, I 
agree Zoe Saldana didn't necessarily bring it in terms of her acting, but 
you can't deny that she sold her action scenes extremely well (and I would 
make the same argument for Karen Gillan's Nebula). Finally, you mentioned 
that you don't think that there is enough demand for a sequel. As someone 
who is currently enrolled in film school and spends a lot of time on many 
different movie news websites, I can tell you that everyone I know in real 
life is extremely excited about the sequel, and everything I've read on the 
internet shows that the worldwide fanbase is ecstatic as well. Last I 
checked, it's tracking to almost outperform Cap 2 at the box office this 
weekend. I hope maybe this has helped to change your opinion about what was 
my favorite Marvel movie so far, but I realize you are entitled to your 
opinion as well. ﻿

fact.

the new movie but they should do a little better job at making it less 
jarring on the new members in the audience.

P.S. I was glad that the origin story was compacted into first half of the 
movie. I know that I couldn't have sat through an entire Drax movie prior 
and I'm not convinced that I would be willing to in the future. It would be 
nice to get a little more of his back story but honestly a few of the

I'm not in the movie industry but I always thought that movies are very 
subject to interpretation depending on how scenes are edited.  For 
instance, the present and letter given to Peter.  It's very subject to 
interpretation.  You saw it as a missed opportunity to have his character 
connect with his mother and the name "Star Lord".  I saw it as confirmation 
to his name whether he created himself or if one of the Ravagers gave it to 
him when he was a boy and he just thought, "Hey, that's cool.  I'll run 
with it."  And in that moment, he connected with his mother with her 
confirmation. 

As for Dave Batista's performance, I have to say that I thought he was 
playing the straight man of the group so his performance worked.  I'm not 
familiar with any of these characters so I can't say that I expected his 
performance to be any different.  Given the limited time, I thought his 
exposition as to what motivated his character was enough. 

My big disappointment was more with Ronan.  They didn't show why he needed 
to be feared.  It was all done through exposition so he lost a lot of what 
could have made him threatening.  Plus how the heck was Peter powering his 
Walkman after 26 years? ﻿

lot of what you said. (Although Thanos was horrible) But nonetheless I 
really do respect you as a movie reviewer and love how well thought out 
these reviews are even if they sometimes (but not often) go counter to my 
thinking. Keep it up :)﻿

I admit I had two problems with this movie coming out of it. It bothered me 
that Yondu had a Southern accent. Perhaps you do have a point concerning 
Michael Rooker not bringing anything to the role. Secondly, it bothered me 
that Rocket Raccoon what sounded like a Brooklyn accent. He sounded like an 
angry Bugs Bunny. I think as well you may have a point that his mother 
calling him Star-Lord should have been referenced earlier in the film, 
perhaps at the beginning. 

Beyond that, I thought Guardians of the Galaxy was spectacular. I felt that 
Chris Pratt did a good job getting out of that lovable doofus thing he's 
got going on in Parks and Recreation. Gamora may be that deadliest assassin 
in the galaxy, but she hates Thanos for making her that. So, she's not 
going to go around killing people when she doesn't have to or whatever you 
would prefer her to be doing. I don't feel there was much of a romance 
angle played up between Peter Quill and Gamora. There was just that whole 
thing about "pelvic sorcery" which made me laugh. Dave Bautista as Drax the 
Destroyer I will say again surprised me with how good he was in the role. 
And you know metaphors from foreign cultures can be difficult to understand 
for anyone. Rocket and Groot were awesome; no fault in that. Was Vin Diesel 
underutilized? Perhaps. I've heard rumors that he might be offered a second 
role from Marvel. That may make up for it. Seeing Thanos fully for the 
first time in one of these movies really excited me. Karen Gillan as 
Nebula... I'm a Doctor Who fan. I will always love her no matter what. It 
was funny seeing John C. Reilly as a Nova Corps dude. Ronan getting 
distracted by Peter Quill suddenly dancing worked because it was the last 
thing anyone would expect to happen given the circumstances. It's just one 
of those things you have to stop and just contemplate why this is 
happening. The Collector honestly I have yet to see Thor: The Dark World so 
I have not opinion on that. But you know seeing Howard the Duck at the end 
shocked me because it was absolutely the last thing I expected to ever see. 
Overall, there's no denying Guardians of the Galaxy was a film that was a 
real risk for Marvel to make. Opinions such as yours clearly illustrate 
what they were afraid of. But I think James Gunn and Marvel took something 
no one expected to work and pulled it off. I look forward to the sequel. 
And I look forward to seeing the Guardians of the Galaxy team up with the 
Avengers like we know they're going to eventually. ﻿

I really like 90's movies and Troma films! And I quite liked this movie 
too. I think the Marvel universe is expansive enough for one of it's 
properties to not take itself so seriously. I had very little prior 
knowledge of these characters before viewing this movie, and what little I 
did hear only lowered my expectations. However, I'm happy to say I was 
surprised by every one of The Guardians.

Bautista delivered way more than anyone was expecting from a wrestler. But

At least Gamora didn't come off as your typical vacant eyed-femme fatal.

I thought she was pretty bad-ass.

Yes, Rocket Raccoon and Groot were great... Yes Rocket Raccoon and Tony 
Stark need a buddy-cop one shot movie. And Yes, the villains /plot were a 
little boring. But the humor more that made up for those weaknesses.

I thought Peter Quill was an enjoyable FUNNY protagonist. So what if he 
didn't have his non-existent six pack on display the whole time. It was 
really cool to see Andy-in-space. And they made sure to have him save the 
cat at least! Ya know, he got in a fight because those kids killed a frog, 
he got all frozen and stuff to save Gamora... he was cool. I wanna go 
cruising in his space ship listening to oldies and... I just realized this 
is a movie for potheads. That explains your disconnect Grace.

For me, this ones going in my summer comedy stack along with Men in Black 
and Ghostbusters. Also, not amazing movies, but enjoyable all the same.

Overall, I had a badass time with this movie.  I laughed and I teared up.  
I walked out of their feeling great.  No, it was certainly not to the level 
of quality that Winter Soldier was, but it definitely delivered on what the 
trailers promised me.  I had a lot of the same issues you did, Grace, but 
over all, I am satisfied with what I saw.  My take on each of your points 
follows:

I was fine that there was a crap ton of characters. In fact, for this 
movie, I liked it.  While I appreciate your point about the benefit of 
spending time with each one like we did with the Avengers, I thought a nice 
balance was struck here between giving us a variety of characters and 
enough time for us to get just the insight we needed

I like that we didn't find out that Quill's mom referred to him as Starlord 
until the end, I liked that the whole time we're laughing at him for it but 
then it gets revealed that there's a serious reason why he wants that name.

I totally agree that Gamora got rescued way to much.    Why didn't she pick 
up on Peter and Rocket's strategy to use the mining pods to bash the 
necro-ships instead of trying to run away from them?  And when Quill 
rescued her from the cold of space, emotionally I was like "Yay, he saved 
her", but intellectually I'm like "Goddamn that was cliche, the feminists 
are going to have a field day with this."  While I can see how a love story 
added balance to the film overall, something was missing here.  I also felt 
that the bulk of her acting was TV-quality at best, and I had to ignore her 
wooden delivery the way I have to ignore the wooden acting in a lot of TV 
shows.

Drax bothered me at first too, but when Rocket explained that he was 
"totally literal" I was able to go with it.

Rocket and Groot were the highlight of the show for sure. Loved them.  They 
could totally hold there own in a Rocket & Groot movie if done right.  As a 
Vin Diesal fan, I thought the various ways he delivered "I am Groot" were 
delivered in the way that only Vin Diesal can, and it worked perfectly for 
the character.

Thanos was underwhelming for me too: his voice, his lack of swagger, cliche 
plus the opposite of the epicness I expected from Thanos.  But he looked 
cool. 

Ronan was meh, but he worked well enough for me as "just a puppet."

I liked that the Nova Corp were essentially just "space-cops".  When they 
all united there ships to try and keep Ronan back I got all "Fuck yeah the 
calvary is here!"

Nebula was both hit and miss for me.  Her anger was explained by her facial 
expression when Thanos referred to Gamora as his "favorite" daughter, but 
the "Get out of my way" was pretty forced to me.  I liked her voice with 
the FX that were added, much cooler than Gamora's.

Yondu I could have taken or left, but when he took out all those necros 
with his whistle spear, I was like "fuck yeah he's a badass red neck."  
He's now a character I hope we run into again.

The Collector worked for me.

I must be one of the only people in the world who loved the Howard The Duck 
movie back in the 80s ( I was 7 when I saw it ), so when he popped up 
sipping a margarita giving the Collector shit for letting the space-dog 
lick him, I was all "hell yeah! inside joke!"

So yeah, even though there were a LOT of things that bothered me through 
out, and James Gunn doesn't quite have what Joss Whedon does, I still loved 
it over all.﻿

I walked out of the theater happy, and the more I think about it the more I 
have good feelings about the film, that said while watching it and still 
now, I know I don't actually like the movie itself, moreso I like aspects 
of it and those aspects are enough to leave me pleased. First and foremost 
the way the use the great soundtrack, I'm a music fan, particularly a fan 
of 70's music so this was especially the last 3 songs, great for me. I love 
Star-Lord's relationship with the music. I also love how they had this 
roguish, shoot first hero that made me primarily think of Indy. I love that 
the kids in the audience were seemed so enthused by the movie. Every few 
moments they were giggling and saying "wow" and all that stuff that a kid 
should do when watching superhero movies. I mean, let's be honest, 
superheroes were originally made for kids and should still be primarily 
focused of entertaining kids while still be good entertainment for an older 
crowd like Avatar the Last Airbender, something it seems the comics don't 
seem to do. Other than that, I honestly thought the movie was eh at best. 
All the lead characters were fun, the movie moved at a brisk pace but it 
seemed to be formless and lacking in plot. A lot of the jokes floundered 
for me and then there were the cheesy tree light moments with the 
awe-struck music and the blatant Care Bear message. And the way Ronan was 
defeated was horrible. But the Jackson 5/Groot stuff won me back over. 
Howard the Duck won me over. And damn it, they had a Marven Gaye song 
featured prominently. How could I not walk away happy. And now I end my 
novel.﻿

Im sorry but you are way off here, im not a hard core fan and i have never 
seen a Guardians comic but i loved this film. Your view of Gamora is the 
one i take issue with most. Her relationship with Nebula is clearly 
explained in that Gamora is the adopted but favorite daughter, in essence 
it sibling rivalry mixed with Nebula`s inherited lunacy. For me i think she 
comes across as very human but entirely badass in that she has been trained 
to be this monstrous assassin but in her heart she is everything but.  Her 
scene when she first arrives in prison emotes genuine fear and a feeling of 
being a duck out of water and when she walks through the inmates with her 
head slightly dipped its like an attempt to lock the negativity out. To me 
she clearly is someone that sees and hates how she is being viewed. She is 
someone brought up in the equivalent of a cult and always under their 
influence, now she is separate from that structure, possibly for the first 
time and so becomes a character in conflict, in a way its nature versus 
nurture. When Star Lord saves her from Drax for no other reason than its 
the right thing to do and then she witnesses Rockets brilliant escape plan 
you can clearly see this that she enjoys being part of this potential team 
and sees the good in some of its members. Remember its her knowledge of the 
danger of the infinity stone that is driving the team forward, not Star 
lords leadership.

In her final battle with Nebula this inner conflict comes to an end and you 
see her displaying all her kickass skills but also is attempting to save 
her sister in the way she has been saved. Its her final seen with Drax that 
concludes Gamoras story arc. She walks through the Milano and just lays her 
hand on Drax`s shoulder and the two share a quick glance and smile, the 
look lasts less than a second but is one i am very familiar with. Ever 
walked into a crowded bar and spotted a good friend of yours and the two of 
you give each other a half smile and nod of the head? you are old friends, 
there doesn't need to be a big public gesture, the smile says good to see 
you mate and the nod says "yeah buddy,we are  grabbing a few beers as soon 
as i find a few seats for the Missus and her friends". Drax and Gamora have 
become friends and i believe that through Drax`s acceptance of Gamora she 
is now better able to accept herself.

To me this movie is as much about Gamora finding her place as it is about 
Star Lord finding his and she shows real progression through out the film 
and i liked it because of her. Im no movie genius and  i think we all take 
different things away from films but again i state; you are way off on your 
judgement of Guardians in particular your judgement of Gamora.﻿

I watched the non spoiler review before watching the movie, and I was so 
sad, because I always trusted your professional sayings about the cinematic 
industry production! And I had big expectations for this movie, I was sad, 
even considered not going to the theaters to watch it. 

But thanks God I did go. This movie is amazing, is fresh, something so 
different, awesome. It kept me interested, it made me curious, it brought 
me to places never seen before, with peculiar characters who acted so 
interesting. 

Peter Quill is a supposed dumb young man, who steals things for living, for 
himself he's a nobody, he's not heroic, although he is slowly turning into 
that. You can't ask more of the persona on the moment. Look the people he 
grew up with, bunch of stupid thieves, what else you would want from him 
the personage? He is suppose to be that dumb, funny dude, with pick up 
lines, but with some flairs of a hero and a leader. I felt that. Who could 
drag that crew together? Think about that.

Gamorra was reinvented, a suddenly doubtful woman, who wants to redeem 
herself. She could have been more important as you wanted, but that would 
drag to much attention to her, and this movie is about the GOTG, not 
Gamorra. She's a killer bot who is in search of her sentimental feelings, 
that was awesome. 

Drax, I think Bautista was the perfect match for that. He's not an actual 
actor, that was the funny of it. A clumsy dumb killer, who has no problems 
killing people, but at the same time he has a heart, but he fails to 
express he's feelings, because he makes them look so fake, as if he's not 
good at it. That was funny. 

Rocket Raccoon, was awesome, a smart modified animal, who acts like a 
human, with a killer humor, badass, but at the same time fragile on the 
inside. Acted so natural, it was like those raccoons actually existed, I 
believed in its existence. 

Groot, represented life at its best form. Within all that machinery he was 
the other side. Badass and funny. Monster and human actions. Tha mix of a 
so different character was awesome.

Ronan, was okay, he was weak of course, more because of his brains. But I 
think that was wanted by the producers. 

Thanos, we had only a glimpse. He did not do anything else but talked to 
Ronan, so we can't judge him. But acted like he knew what was going to 
happen to Ronan, so he didnt even care about him. And that's powerful for 
me. 

How come you say there was no sentimental things on this movie? The idea of 
a team of the weirdest crew? The turning of a playa like Quill into someone 
who saves the girl? The girl who feels things but do not want to? Groot?? 
There was a strong feeling attachment for me on the movie. 

The movie is simple, and is hard to understand how they were able to do 
that. Because the story seems so complicated and confused, and it would be 
boring. But look at that the turned into a simple and funny movie. And I 
want more.

Wow, so much heat on this topic. The movie was definitely entertaining, but 
I'm with Grace for a lot of points. I found the emotional aspects of the 
story shallow and some better writing is needed for the sequel. Rocket and 
Groot were standouts, but I was disappointed that there wasn't a better 
balance of light-hearted/jokiness versus the gravitas of Ronan destroying a 
whole planet. And the music got old really quickly. I'd put it at Thor: 
Dark World level also, and Iron Man 1 was definitely better - handling that 
story and the humor/drama with more sophistication. I left the cinema 
feeling a bit short changed. I really wanted this to be awesome but it 
didn't live up to its 92% rating. It was merely good. 
I'm not sure why it's got such a high Tomato rating, but it's probably an 
indication that the dark and heavy comic movies have run their course and 
are trending out.
Additionally, there were some shocking moments of bad science in the movie 
- despite a talking Racoon being present - and even for it being set in a 
Marvel universe deep space should still be deep space and the rules should 
apply: and they did it twice which took me out of the movie badly. (Trying 
not include spoilers.)﻿

I agree that Ronan was very underplayed: yeap, not enough action on him.

I agree that Nebula has not enough to expand on: really, almost didn't give

once a father, remember?)
I don't agree that the film is as bad as you would criticize it: I feel 
that it is above average. And because it is a different take on the Marvel 
Cinematic Universe, I was quite intrigued and surprised (in a good way) to

direction before, therefore it is fresh.

Ok to the spoilers! I agree that the movie was Rocket's and Groot's. They 
were my absolute favorite things in this film. And I actually quite loved 
that Vin Diesel was the voice of Groot because it reminded me so much of 
when he did the voice of The Iron Giant. It makes me wonder if they did 
that on purpose.
To be fair, I don't think all the Marvel films need to be Cap 2, which is 
still far and away the best film I've seen this year, so I had fun with 
this film. I went in not knowing a lot but I guess my faith in Marvel is 
allowing me to be ok with not knowing a lot. I just tell myself, "Well, 
it'll make sense once it's time for it." LOL Also, I personally really 
enjoy the Thor films though I acknowledge that they are flawed, so I am 
fond of this film in the same way.
I was also wondering why they threw that tidbit on Starlord's father at the 
end with like one line. Either they should have dove in a little more or 
just kept it out of the film and make it a big thing in the sequel. I 
thought that was poorly handled.
Again, this could have been a good villain but we got the same old bad guy 
who for... reasons wants to destroy a planet and he wants to do so with a 
powerful weapon but our heroes stop them. It can only work so many times. 
At least with Loki we understand that it's because he's mentally unstable 
and he's doing it to piss off his father and brother. But we had a whole 
previous film to build that up.
I hope Marvel isn't blind to the problems they still have, and will improve 
them rather than ignore them and just eat up the good stuff they have 
going. I want more female roles where they are part of a team and a fleshed 
out character not just one of the hero's love interest. So far, The 
Avengers and Cap 2 have done well with that. I want good villains who have 
more purpose than just destroying/taking over a planet.
So Guardians of the Galaxy isn't perfect but I really enjoyed it, and I 
liked the acting in the movie. And I hope you know that I still love your 
reviews Grace. I'm glad that you're honest with your opinions rather than 
lie and say you like it just to appease to the people angry with you right 
now. LOL Hope the next movie you see will be one you enjoy more. :)﻿

I just saw GotG and unfortunately Grace is correct on her larger points. I 
didn't agree with some of the smaller points about Nebula (her voice was 
synthesized) and Drax (Batista did a fine job), but she is right that 
Gamora was represented poorly in the film and the motivations of the 
villains are very unclear. 

Overall, it was a fine summer 'blockbuster. I thought the CG was some of 
the best I've seen, there were plenty of laughs, and most of the characters 
were fun. However, there were some bad leaps of logic, some too-quick story 
telling, and they really flubbed one of the main characters (Gamora) in my 
opinion.

I would rate Guardians as the 4th or 5th best marvel movie after my first 
viewing. So, not bad, but not great either.﻿
