This seemed bias by your own disappointment. And you're totally allowed 
that, but it just doesn't seem fair or professional to generalize an entire 
audience. I have never read a comic (my husband has), and I enjoyed this 
thoroughly. It was fun, heartwarming, with serious franchise potential. It 
is PG-13, and my husband and I took our daughter and she loved it, but we 
did know it's rating. And I think it's at the parents discretion, but it's 
not grossly vulgar or insulting. I loved the soundtrack, classics and 
played perfectly to great effect. But I also don't believe the film needed 
a heavy origin for each character, including saving Peter's father, who my 
husband tells me is some kind of royalty, for the sequel. I was happy we 
could jump right into the film and hit the ground running.

It felt like Star Wars, you were dropped in, and told to go with it. I did, 
and I loved it. I am tired of the heavy origins, we're in a post origin 
world now, I hope, and i think it's time to find new ways to approach 
introducing these characters. And Guardians handled it deftly.

As for his Starlord alias, I really loved that it was saved for the end, it 
just added a retroactive depth and heart. I, honestly, felt it was better 
applied than fed at the beginning.

This layered approach to origins was fair. The first act wasn't an info 
dump, and I didn't feel like being spoon-fed again. This was a great way to 
handle introducing a cast of characters. Especially a group like the 
Guardians.

Ronan was one of the most solid villains Marvel has had in a while. He's a 
religious, genocidal zealot, with far stronger motivations than the Dark 
Elves or even Red Skull. In my opinion. I totally got what he wanted, 
however simplistic, but at least his motives were clear.

Nebula was far too underutilized, I wanted more of her. I felt like she was 
the jealous daughter/sister, and wanted Thanos' approval, but that's me 
drawing conclusions, and I get not everyone will create their own canon.

Groot was fantastic, Vin Diesel really nailed the role. I've heard several 
actors, from Michael Clark Duncan to Kevin Michael Richardson, and none 
have brought the heart and character to the role. And I was so shocked to 
find how much Vin brought to the role with limited dialogue. But it really 
matters. And he nailed it.

Rocket was the best thing about this movie, my husband wants the Adventures 
of Rocket & Groot, they were the stars.

But you're generalizations are unfair, audiences have loved this movie, 
leaving the theater thrilled, everyone I know has seen it with their 
families, and some have seen it twice. This is all hearsay, but this film 
will have a strong following. And more people want the sequel than you 
think. And it's really not your place to determine what audiences want. 
It's your place to give a review, not tell us how we should feel. Which is 
what you were doing.

I want a sequel. I loved the film and I had never heard of these people. I 
followed it easily. And I thought this film managed the origins in the most 
apt, best way possible, by using the whole of the film, instead of an info 
dump in the first act. The best stories can handle these, and Guardians did 
solidly.

Was the movie in love with itself? Absolutely. The poster even says; 
"You're Welcome." And it's that attitude that made this film the best. I 
loved it.

I respectfully disagree, and you're totally allowed your opinion. I just 
disagree with your statement that only hardcore fans can get this film. 
That's insulting to me and kids who love it. And that is definitely not 
your right, and I don't respect that. It's why I initially had to respond.

Thanos felt, to me, like Palpatine in Empire Strikes Back, his first 
appearance over the hologram. You don't really know or understand why you 
should fear him, or why these villains do. But you sort of get it. I have 
no idea who Josh Brolin is, but I loved Thanos, for his few moments anyway.﻿

I have to agree and disagree with some of your points. I agree with you 
about Rocket & Groot, and also on the underwhelming performance of Gamora 
(possibly Saldana as an extension of that). I felt that Gamora should have 
been way more tough and should have fought ten times better. The inmates at 
the prison should have left her alone because of her reputation for being 
the deadliest assassin in the galaxy.

I feel similar about Drax, who should have been a lot more powerful than he 
was. However, I thought Bautista's acting was great for this character 
(especially the deadpan humor). Quill is hard for me to get 100% behind but 
I did understand his character, his motives, and the dance-off at the end 
was so random that it caused Ronan (plenty powerful but underdeveloped) to 
pause deciding whether it was an attack or not, which was sufficient time 
for Rocket to re-build his super-gun.

I thought the team worked well together and can continue to work well 
together. We don't need origin stories movies for every character of every 
team we want to make into a movie. This movie did enough, in my opinion, to 
satisfy everyone's origin (except for Ronan) reducing the need for origin 
movies. Thanos should have been given an action sequence, if only to put 
Ronan in his place and that would have really improved Thanos's appearance 
and build up fear of him.

The Nova corp was a cool idea but seemed more like an after-thought, or at 
least was treated that way. Again, another example of underpowering 
powerful characters. (But i really like the uniforms of the ones wearing 
helmets; I'm a huge Nova fan.) It would have also been cool had the scene 
with Nova Prime discussing Ronan's actions on Xandarian outposts to a Kree 
official, if we caught a glimpse of the Supreme Intelligence. But again 
that's just a fan-boy clamoring for more.

All in all, it was a great movie, maybe just edging out Winter Soldier, but 
hard to compare when they are such different movies. Sorry for the long 
reply, but thank you, Grace, for your honest opinions.﻿

Peter Quill:  I enjoyed his character.  I agree with you that his back 
story could have been handled in the sequel which will likely include his 
Father.  Unlike you I really didn't like the opening scene.  None of the 
acting there sold me.  The Mom didn't look sick so much as she did an 
alien.  I went with my younger siblings and they both thought that she was 
an Alien.  So I didn't like that at all.  It only served to tie to movie in 
with the Marvel Cinematic Universe in that it established how we could have 
a sci-fi movie that takes place alongside the rest of the MCU.  But I think 
Chris Pratt did a good job.  He was funny and I thought he acted as a good 
balance for the rest of the cast.  But they definitely didn't sell his own 
emotional scenes.  The opening of the present was lame.  I was hoping it 
was something from his Father but as soon as he told Gamora that his mom 
loved sharing her favourite music with him then I knew I was going to be 
disappointed with that reveal.

Gamora:  I agree with you in that Gamora was a poorly written and depicted 
character in this film.  I didn't buy the romance that they tried to push 
with Quill.  I wasn't invested in her back story at all.  Hell, I liked 
Nebula more than her and I've just about completely forgotten Nebula's 
motives in the movie.  Only that she wants Thanos dead just like Gamora. 
 So yeah.  Of the Guardian's, Gamora is the weakest link.  I do think 
though that Zoe Saldana did her best with what was given.  I didn't find 
her acting as flat as you apparently did.

Drax:  This was the biggest surprise for me.  When I heard Batista had been 
given the role I was skeptical at best.  Those first few scenes didn't help 
at all.  But the humor with his character eventually won me over.  I loved 
at how metaphors went right over his head (Thought nothing goes over his 
head.  His reflexes are too fast xD).  My biggest qualm with Drax was at 
how weak he seemed when he fought just about everyone outside of the Prison 
escape.  For someone with the name of the Destroyer he sure lacked any epic 
fight scene.  I would have thought that he would have been able to do a 
little more to Ronin but alas that wasn't the case.  But I thought Batista 
did the deadpan humor quite well (better than his intimidation in the 
Prison that is for sure) and the feels with him were more believable than 
with Quill or Gemora.

Rocket and Groot:  Totally agree with you.  They won the show for me. 
 Rocket was nearly flawless.  MY only beef with Groot was that he was a 
deus ex machina character.  When the Guardians were in a bind, Groot to the 
rescue.  Guess he had to make up for taking that purple battery out so 
early in the movie.

Thanos:  This is where I disagree with you almost completely.  Thanos 
wasn't the villain of this movie.  He didn't need to be flashy or overly 
active.  He is the big bad in the MCU.  He can afford to listless when it 
comes to the little threat that Ronin posses to him and that was really 
what he was up against.  He's the man with the plan.  He doesn't need to be 
rushed to get just one Infinity stone.

Ronan:  Had some cool scenes but was too one dimensional.  So yeah, I 
mostly agree with you here.  Marvel really needs to tune in that to have a 
successful CU they need good persistent villains as much as they need their 
heroes.

Nebula:  I liked her more than Gemora.  Though she was far, far, from 
perfect.

Yondu:  I disagree here too.  I thought the actor did a fine job for the 
role.  I don't like at how they explained his connection to Quill by him 
being hired to take him back.  But it was heavily implied from the early 
scenes with him that he had some connection to Quill beyond just abducting 
him so I did like that.

But yeah.  Over all I really liked this movie.  It wasn't great.  Marvel 
movies have definitely lost their novelty and it will take more than what 
we have been given to truly impress me but I didn't feel like I wasted 
money seeing it.  I would recommend anyone who has been enjoying the MCU to 
see it.  People who haven't been able to get into it, this won't be the 
movie to get you watching Superhero movies.﻿

!!!!!SPOILERS!!!!!! and rant I guess.
Lost? I have never read more than a few random Marvel comics and that was 
in the late 90s. I have seen the Marvel movies but some I found super 
boring and didn't care to memorise all the fancy names for the fancy 
artefacts and so on. And still, this film was a walk in the park plot wise. 
I had not a single moment when I felt I don't know what the scene is about. 
The plot is very consistent and easy to follow. and even though I totally 
failed to register any previous mentions of infinity stones (in other 
movies) after this flick I got the message, they are some big evil prize 
for the big evil guy.
And Peter is a very likeable character, and I loved they skipped the origin 
story because these origin setting up films are all the same. I waited for 
him to open the package the whole movie, wondering what's in it and I loved 
that they made me wait. Is it info on his obviously space dad (aliens 
wouldn't have abducted him just moments after his mother told him that his 
dad is going to come back for him if he didn't have a space dad... that was 
super obvious for anyone with two neurons to rub together)? Is it some 
magical weapon or space treasure? Will the box contents save them in the 
end? I loved that he struggled with opening it and hid it. This actually 
told the viewer a lot about his character. And when he finally opened the 
box it was super cheesy and made me very happy. I mean this is a film with 
a final battle resolved like in Sailor Moon finale and the tape just worked 
really well after that.
I also loved how Gomora never bought for a moment his cheap lines. I loved 
her complicated relationship with Nebula. And Nebula is not angry for being 
angry. We can clearly see she feels abandoned by Gomora. And she doesn't 
like to have it rubbed in that she is not the favourite "daughter", even 
though she hates the big evil dude as much as everyone else does. And she 
doesn't dig the lame douche with the hammer either and she is stuck with 
him. <-- you telling me that he is another reformed villain turned hero in 
the comics makes me happy they killed him in the film, or at least I hope 
they did. This evil turned good routine is so old and lame. And so overused 
in these never-ending stories, where the writers are not allowed to come to 
any conclusion, because they cannot finish a series once and for all 
because it would cut off the money flow, but they are running out of ideas 
so they get a minor villain to come to the good side... *eye roll*
I loved that none of the heroes was overpowered. And Gomora truly needed 
saving only in the space scene, where she was at a disadvantage from the 
start of the chase and it was obvious she won't run away, because that 
would completly make no sense. Not in the prison though - in prison she is 
a typical tactician waiting for a moment when it would be least risky to 
take action. the fact that the infinity stone is this typical comic book 
overpowered, over the top, sad plot device is the only thing that didn't 
really work for me in this movie.
And really I would like to dispute almost every single point you made in 
this review, but seriously I don't think it would matter or change you 
mind, also my comment is super long as it is.
To sum up I find is startling that I, a person who has a very limited 
knowledge of Marvel universe, had absolutely no problem with this film and 
with how it sets up its characters and you a comic book specialist found it 
hard to follow and imho failed to notice more than half of the interesting 
stuff in it. The script here was very clear and had very pleasant character 
development which is almost absent in many other Marvel movies which makes 
them boring to people who do not dig the whole superhero mythos. And sure 
as hell I don't. And this is why the Winter soldier, the Guardians and 1st 
Thor are the only marvel films resonating with me to the point of actually 
enjoying them - they do not have the typical super hero in goofy outfit 
saves the day vibe and that is actually cool.  ﻿

Firstly I have seen your coverage of the trailers and such and I don't

have been wondering who will take up Harrison Ford's mantle). To say that 
Pratt seemed like he was still acting in Parks and Recreation is totally 
unfair. And again if you liked the tone and humour and performance in the 
trailers then why not the movie? What changed Grace?

Next you criticise the film for being too slow (which it wasn't) but then 
you complain that there wasn't enough background, explanation, and 
character development which would have slowed the movie down. You can't 
have the best of both worlds Grace and you have to admit that you totally 
(and unfairly) contradicted yourself in this review to criticise this 
(totally awesome) movie. Also you loved Xmen days of future past and yet 
that movie was criticised in many reviews for being too slow (or more 
accurately slowing down towards the middle). You never criticised Xmen for 
this and instead showered the film in praise despite it not being a totally 
perfect movie. 

I believe that the core of your criticism (the source of your 
disappointment) comes from the weak female characters. Now I want to be 
fair, I respect your opinions and I respect you as a female movie goer and 
I respect your feminist leanings however I believe that it is this aspect 
of your opinions that has coloured your views on this movie. If this movie 
had had strong female characters and a feminist subplot (like malificent) 
then I bet you would have given this movie a much better review. I do agree 
that the female characters in this movie were weak and sidelined and I vet 
that that must be frustrating for you as a female movie goer. Glamor a 
wasn't the deadly assassin that she could have been. However I think that 
they had to bring balance to the guardians team, Gamora had to fit into it 
and be somewhat equal to them. Plus Gamora didn't get many scenes in 
general in this movie but with so much to cover that isn't surprising. She 
also wasn't explored much as a character or given any development but again 
that is to be expected in this movie. But seeing as how she is the daughter 
of Thanos we know that she will become more central to the plot in future 
movies and hopefully not only will we be able to explore her background and 
see some character development but she will get more scenes and hopefully 
we will see her kick more ass and be the cool assassin we know she is! I 
would also like to ask why it is that you don't like Zoe Saldana? You dump 
on her in pretty much everything she is in (including this movie) and yet 
she is a very very successful female actress (a female actress of colour no 
less) that is in 3 major blockbuster franchises. I respect your opinion to 
dislike her but to dump on her in every review and to give actresses like 
Hali Berry a free pass for piss poor performances just doesn't seem fair to 
me (her portrayal as Storm in Xmen is disrespectful to that character and 
the franchise).I think that Nebula was pretty terrible and badly portrayed 
by Karen Gillan. I am a whovian and she is good in that show however 
without her pretty good looks and in this emotionally dead character she 
had a difficult time. Again though there was no background to her character 
and she didn't get many scenes to impress us. Hopefully in the next film 
again she will have more opportunities to improve and have more to do. 
(Also I thought her costume and make up was a bit off, I wish they had made 
her look more like a kree version of Ventress from Star Wars rather than 
some weird cyborg with a patchwork of different shades of blue makeup).

Finally I would like to defend Dave Bautista (something I never thought I 
would say). You were totally harsh on him given that he did a surprisingly 
good job. Was he brilliant? No. But he did a good job with the (very well 
written) material he was given. I also think that he did a good job with 
his fight scenes and it was cool to see some actual fight scenes in a 
marvel movie (like in Captain America) rather than just a load of CGI fake 
green screen action. Dave Bautista isn't an acting genius but he was well 
imagined as Drax. I actually wish that the Rock (Dwayne Johnsone) would 
watch this and give up on trying to act and just play to his strengths. You 
give Dwayne Johnsone a pass all of the time but he cannot act any better 
than Dave Bautista and at least James Gunn realised Dave Bautista's 
limitations and gave him lines that he could effectively deliver (which he 
did again and again to the hilarity of the whole movie theatre). 

Also I did love Groot and Rocket, I too thought they were adorable. Would I 
want to see an entire movie of them though? He'll no. Why? Because they 
need to be balanced with the whole team. On their own they wouldn't be any 
where near as effective or funny. Plus there is no background or character 
development to explore with them. The shot of Rocket's back was all that 
needed to be said. They have their use in future team movies but alone they 
would have no success. 

I hope that your coverage going forward is fair and not still coloured by 
your opinions. If this movie does do very well this weekend at the box 
office and if it is considered a mainstream success and it does get a 
sequel then much like with Frozen I think you are going to have to accept 
that you are in the minority and go along with the franchises success 
(though I actually agreed with your opinions on Frozen, I was a fan of the 
initial concept art and not the finished product). 

One last thing actually before I forget; Thanos didn't get much coverage in 
this movie however I think that as Avengers Age of Ultron is still a year 
off and that he is the big bad in avengers 3 which is who knows how many 
years away how could they give him much coverage? Also they had to give 
screen time to Ronan the Accuser who despite being the main villain still 
wasn't given enough coverage and was a bit of a weak villain. I think you 
are just going to have to be patient for Thanos like the rest of us. Also I 
am not a Howard the Duck fan but I liked the end credit scene and the fan 
boys in the theatre I was in went crazy for it. Those kind of nods to the 
fans are what makes Marvel's movies fun. Also given that the next Marvel 
movie is Avengers 2 what could they have done for the end credit scene with 
Guardians being so far removed from the Avengers atm? For now Guardians is 
a stand alone movie and we are going to have to wait for phase 3 for that 
to change. Therefore they had a end credit scene which they couldn't do 
much with and so they decided on doing some fan service. Is that fair to 
criticise? Nope. Fan service is a good thing, especially when Marvel does 
it. 

Hope you understand where I am coming from x﻿

I think your opinion that we need origin story after origin story before 
getting the team up is completely off. We don't need to know every detail 
about a character to be entertained by them in a movie, and this movie 
played beautifully off of what we did learn about them. It gave some 
beautiful insight into each of the main characters without making us wait 
years while they set up everyone's background. Ensemble movies have done 
this for decades before comics came along and none of them ever needed 
origins before coming together. 
 Saying this film was slow paced because they had to set up back stories is 
a completely ludicrous statement IMO, this films packed with humor, action, 
as well as backstory and its all balanced beautifully. This is the one film 
from Marvel that doesn't feel like everything else, and its a refreshing 
change of pace.
 I don't know where you saw any romance shared between Peter and Gamora, 
from seeing it twice its pretty obvious that the affection was more one 
sided than anything. Peter being the flirtatious tool constantly hitting on 
Gamora, and her turning him down up until the end where she gains a respect 
for him for his bravery and heart worked great. It wasn't a comic book 
romance by any means, and was done extremely well IMO.
 Putting blame on Bautista for "wooden" acting pretty much misses the point 
of the character he portrayed. It obviously went way over your head, I 
guess your reflexes weren't fast enough. He's a no-nonsense, extremely 
literal character that is only driven by revenge. His character didn't 
require a thespian level actor, and it was a nice surprise from what we all 
probably thought would've been the big muscle head with no speaking roles. 
His comedic timing was incredible and while he's not an amazing actor, he's 
never claimed to be and the character doesn't try to be either. Saying he 
got the role because he's just some big guy with cool tats is pretty 
sexist. If someone said Zoe Saldana got the role because of her ass that 
would be met with some pretty heavy criticism, and its not fair to use that 
same mentality towards Batista.
 You seem to have a problem because the villains weren't fleshed out main 
characters. I don't think that argument works here, not every villain needs 
to be Loki. Mystery is a good thing, we learned what was needed for the 
movie. We don't need to see every aspect of their lives or sympathize with 
them as a villain. Ronan was a loyal Kree citizen unhappy with the treaty, 
he was a terrorist, do you really want to sympathize with a terrorist? It 
pretty obvious they're setting Thanos up as a truly mythic creature in this 
universe that is feared throughout the galaxies. The constant name drops 
showed just how well known and feared he is, and his nonchalant attitude 
towards Ronan was a good way of showing his power IMO. It showed that he's 
powerful, and even when Ronan has the infinity stone he's not intimidated. 
Thats what you need for a villain like Thanos. As for Nebula she really 
worked for me, she's a heartless, ruthless killer. It works, as for her 
anger, I'm pretty sure most of that comes from jealousy of Gamora. The line 
where Thanos calls Gamora his favorite daughter you can really see the 
anger and jealousy in Nebula and it was done really well.
 The end credit scene was a nice addition, this film didn't try to take 
itself too seriously, it was a fun movie that took a different direction 
than the typical Marvel movie, which is something much needed. Marvel's 
films fit a mold, and this was a nice break from that mold. Its a movie set 
in space where a few stones can destroy the universe, it shouldn't be taken 
in the same direction as Cap2. People need to remember that there's no law 
that says you need an end credit scene. They're fun little easter eggs to 
add an extra laugh at the end of the movie. This was like the shawarma 
scene. Not everything needs to lead into the next film. Sometimes a stand 
alone film is the best approach. And out of every Marvel property, GotG was 
the most appropriate place to add a reference like Howard the Duck in.
 I think you and a few others are far too invested into the direction 
Marvel has taken previously, and anything thats different from that 
direction is met with resistance. Changes of pace are always welcomed and 
shouldn't be seen as a bad thing. We need diversity in the comic book genre 
or else we get the same stagnant direction that we get from Iron Man 2, 
Iron Man 3, and Thor 2. Calling this film unprofessional really undermines 
just how great this movie actually is. I'm someone who's not a fan of your 
typical Marvel Studios production, I think they're all pretty stale paint 
by numbers films that throw in easter eggs and try to paint themselves as 
deep intellectual movies. This one offers something different and 
refreshing﻿

from being entertained by and enjoying the movie. I agree with everything

I watched this film, and Grace, like the last several times on different 
topics, I have to respectfully disagree with you. :)

First, Ronan himself is definitely an impressive villain. He's imposing, 
has a lot of charisma, power oozes out of him, he has his flaws, his 
amazing abilities, is a genuine threat - easily the second best Marvel 
Studios villain after Loki. Nebula falls under these ranks as well. She was 
just a delight to watch, especially due to the fact that, robotic as she 
is, she lost her cool not once, but twice during the movie. Quite a sweet 
fit for Karen Gillian.

Second, Gamora was saved a grand total of one and a half times, the same 
amount as any other Guardian. Once when attacked by Drax (that's the half, 
since she proved a scene before that she could very well save herself), the 
second time while in space, when Star Lord gave her the mask. So for you to 
harp on that so much in the non-spoiler review, it was kind of...well, 
unnecessary. Or rather, completely unnecessary.

Third, James Gunn. This is a big-budget, yet typical James Gunn film. Which 
is an enormous plus. It shows that creativity can indeed play a big role in 
these movies. Not to mention that he used all of his Gunn staples perfectly 
- like Kaufmann, Fillion, etc.

Fourth, Drax. I don't know what movie you've seen, but Dave Bautista did 
his job perfectly. He shows actual, legitimate skill in acting, and is more 
than mere muscle of the group. His lines were delivered amazingly well 
within context, and even his facial expressions commandeered both laughter 
and amazement. Again, don't know if we saw two different movies or not, but 
to me, Bautista is a credible actor.

And finally, a thought on your Captain America comment from your Top Ten 
list. Personally, I have not turned against my love for the Avengers, or 
the X-Men films, or even the Winter Soldier. Fans, true fans, are not 
really that fickle. The Dark Knight comment can also be explained away with 
one simple comment: upon rewatching, the three Nolan Batman movies don't 
really hold up that well. And again, their fanbases are still strong. So I 
would not berate people for claiming that this new movie is their favorite 
just like that.

Now, none of this is meant to change your opinion, of course. Even when we 
consider the matter that throughout your videos you tend to treat your 
opinion as undeniable fact (cases in point: David Goyer as a 
filmmaker/story-man, the impressions on films like Thor the Dark World, 
etc.) Also, this is not meant to insult you or your taste. But I should 
point one more detail. The guys on RedLetterMedia praised this film over an 
indie feature because of the amount of fun in a comic book movie, something 
that was sorely missing from blockbusters in general. So I will raise the 
fun in this movie to a more elevated position, almost a crucial one: this 
movie was made to be fun, and it did it in a spectacular matter. It did not 
have a serious undertone like The Winter Soldier, nor did it pretend to 
have it like Nolan's Batman films.

Hope to hear from you via comments and to argue some more if possible. :D ﻿

Grace, I loved this movie, and based off of Thursday night's 11.2 million 
opening, America did too! I think maybe you disliked this movie because you 
expected a sophisticated and exciting science fiction movie, when we

summer :) ﻿
